title: 115_hr1728
content: Boundary modification for Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area in Idaho. The definitions in this section include the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area, Gateway West high-voltage transmission line project, a map titled "Proposed Snake River Birds of Prey NCA Boundary Adjustment," sage-grouse species, and the Secretary of the Interior. The Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area boundary is modified to include approximately 4726 acres of land managed by the BLM Jarbidge Field Office until terms of a settlement agreement are met. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area boundary is modified to include approximately 4726 acres of land managed by the BLM Jarbidge Field Office until terms of a settlement agreement are met. Additionally, approximately 86 acres of land known as "BOR Administered Lands" will be managed by the conservation area office. The exclusion of approximately 761 acres of land, including the Segment 8 Revised Proposed Route, is also specified to ensure the Gateway West Transmission Line is sited appropriately. The Secretary will issue a right-of-way to Gateway West for the construction and maintenance of transmission lines on approximately 1,845 acres of land, including the Segment 9 Revised Proposed Route and 125 feet on either side of the center line of the Gateway West Transmission line. The Secretary will issue a right-of-way to Gateway West for the construction and maintenance of transmission lines, including access roads and fire prevention activities. The conditions for the right-of-way align with the proposed routes for segments 8 and 9. Mitigation measures will be implemented during construction to address impacts related to the transmission lines. Gateway West will mitigate impacts related to transmission lines according to the Compensatory Mitigation and Enhancement framework, with costs capped at $8,543,440. Additionally, they will contribute $2,000 per acre of right-of-way in the Conservation Area during construction of Segment 8 and Segment 9 to the Bureau of Land Management Foundation. The Bureau of Land Management Foundation will receive 1,845 acres for conservation purposes, including enhancing National Landscape Conservation System Units in Idaho. Gateway West will cover all costs associated with the boundary modification. The Secretary will administer the lands as part of the Conservation Area in accordance with Public Law. The Secretary will administer lands in the Conservation Area according to Public Law and the National Landscape Conservation System. Administrative jurisdiction over 86 acres is transferred to the Bureau of Land Management. A map will be available for public inspection, and a management plan amendment is required within 18 months. The Secretary will amend the management plan for the Conservation Area within 18 months to address long-term management of specific lands, including grazing and motorized access. The Secretary will allow motorized access on existing roads and hunting/fishing on specified lands, subject to necessary regulations and laws. The Cotterel Wind Power Project area on Federal land is prohibited from being used for wind electricity production. The Secretary of the Interior will establish a Bureau of Land Management Foundation as a charitable nonprofit corporation to address specific challenges such as reclamation of legacy wells, sustainable management of wild horses, and expanded scientific understanding. The Bureau of Land Management Foundation will focus on sustainable management of wild horses and burros, expanded scientific understanding of responsible development techniques, voluntary conservation activities, and proper identification of cultural and historical treasures on public lands.
